facts.text: Appeal by special leave arises out of a redemption suit filed by the respondent Dev Karan against the appellant Murarilal.

anchor.surface_text: Gajendragadkar, C.J. This appeal by special leave arises out of a redemption suit filed by the respondent Dev Karan against the appellant Murarilal.

facts.text: Mortgage executed on 19th March 1919 for Rs. 6,500.

anchor.surface_text: The mortgage sought to be redeemed was executed on the 19th March, 1919 for a sum of Rs. 6,500.

facts.text: Mortgaged property consisted of a shop delivered to possession of mortgagee after execution.

anchor.surface_text: The mortgaged property companysisted of a shop which was delivered over in the possession of the mortgagee after the execution of the mortgage deed.

facts.text: Mortgage deed provided repayment within 15 years or mortgagee becomes owner.

anchor.surface_text: The mortgage deed had provided that the amount due under the mortgage should be repaid to the mortgagee within 15 years, whereupon the property would be redeemed. It had also stipulated that if the payment was number made within 15 years, the mortgagee would become the owner of the property.

facts.text: Mortgagor Mangal Ram died; respondent is heir and legal representative.

anchor.surface_text: The mortgagor was Mangal Ram who died and the respondent claims to be the heir and legal representative of the said deceased mortgagor.

facts.text: Original mortgagee Gangadhar died before suit; appellant Murarilal impleaded as heir.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that the original mortgagee Gangadhar had also died before the institution of the suit, and so, the appellant Murarilal was impleaded as the defendant on the basis that he was the only heir and legal representative of the deceased mortgagee Gangadhar.

facts.text: Respondent averred transaction was mortgage, right to redeem alive after 15 years.

anchor.surface_text: In the plaint filed by the respondent, it was averred that the transaction was, in substance, a mortgage and the mortgagors right to redeem was alive even though the stipulated period of 15 years for the repayment of the loan had passed.

facts.text: Respondent claimed decree for redemption on payment of Rs. 6,500.

anchor.surface_text: On these allegations, the respondent claimed a decree for redemption of the suit mortgage on payment of Rs. 6,500.

facts.text: Appellant alleged after 15 years property became absolute property of mortgagee and transaction was sale not mortgage.

anchor.surface_text: The claim for redemption thus made by the respondent was resisted by the appellant on several grounds. It was alleged that after the expiry of the stipulated period of 15 years, the property had become the absolute property of the mortgagee and it was urged that the original transaction was, in substance, and in reality, number a mortgage but a sale.

facts.text: Trial Judge held redemption claim unsustainable after 15 years, dismissed suit.

anchor.surface_text: The learned trial Judge framed appropriate issues which arose on the pleading of the parties. In substance, he held that the claim for redemption made long after the 15 years period had expired companyld number be sustained. Findings were made on other issues also and they were against the respondent. In the result, the respondents suit was dismissed.

facts.text: Respondent appealed to Rajasthan High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent then took the matter in appeal before the Rajasthan High Court.

facts.text: High Court held stipulation is clog on equity of redemption, reversed trial decree, remanded suit.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court has upheld his first companytention that the relevant provision as to the period within which the mortgage amount had to be repaid amounted to a clog on the equity of redemption and companyld number be pleaded as a bar to the present suit. ... On these findings, the decree passed by the trial Court dismissing the respondents suit has been reversed and the suit has been remanded to the trial Court to be disposed of in accordance with law.

facts.text: Appellant came to Supreme Court by special leave against High Court order.

anchor.surface_text: It is against this order that the appellant has companye to this Court by special leave.

facts.text: Pending Supreme Court appeal, both appellant and respondent died, heirs brought on record.

anchor.surface_text: Pending the appeal before this Court, both the appellant and the respondent have died, and their respective heirs have been brought on the record.

facts.text: Amount due under mortgage not paid within 15 years.

anchor.surface_text: It is companymon ground that the amount due under the mortgage deed was number paid by the mortgagor or his heir within the stipulated period and that would extinguish the title of the mortgagor and make the mortgagee to be the owner of the property.

facts.text: Transfer of Property Act did not apply to Alwar at time of mortgage execution or 15 years expiry.

anchor.surface_text: This question arises in this form, because the Transfer of Property Act did number apply to Alwar at the time when the mortgage was executed number at the time when the 15 years stipulated period expired.

facts.text: Mortgage property is a shop/house; mortgagee could live in it or let to tenants.

anchor.surface_text: The first question which calls for our decision is whether the relevant clause on which the appellant relies makes the mortgagee the owner of the property at the end of the stipulated period of 15 years. The mortgage provides, inter alia, that after the house which was the mortgage property was delivered over to the mortgagee, it was open to him either to live in it, or to let it out to tenants.

facts.text: Mortgagee liberty to spend up to Rs. 35 for repairs, more through mortgagor, interest at As. 0-6-0 per cent per month.

anchor.surface_text: The mortgagee was further given liberty to spend up to Rs. 35 for repairing the house and if more expenses were intended to be incurred, the said expenditure would be incurred through the mortgagor. On the expenditure thus incurred the mortgagor was liable to pay interest at the rate of As. 0-6-0 per cent per month.

facts.text: Relevant clause: After expiry of 15 years, shop deemed absolute transfer Mala Kalam for this amount. Till mortgage money paid, mortgagor has no concern.

anchor.surface_text: Then, occurs the relevant clause After the expiry of the stipulated period of 15 years, this shop would be deemed as an absolute transfer Mala Kalam for this very amount. Till the mortgage money is paid, I shall have numberconcern with the shop.

facts.text: High Court viewed 'Mala Kalam' as meaning no scope for having any say, not necessarily absolute ownership.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court appears to have taken the view that the words Mala Kalam which occur at the end of the relevant clause do number necessarily import the numberion that the mortgage property would be the absolute property of the mortgagee. According to the High Court, the said words literally mean where there is numberscope for having any say.

facts.text: Supreme Court held clause intends mortgagee absolute owner after 15 years if not paid.

anchor.surface_text: If that is the meaning of the relevant words, it seems difficult to accept the view that the document did number intend to make the mortgagee the owner of the property at the end of 15 years if the debt due was number paid within that period. ... Therefore, we feel numberdifficulty in holding that if the terms of the document were to prevail, the appellants companytention that the present suit for redemption is barred, must succeed.

facts.text: Stipulation amounts to clog on equity of redemption.

anchor.surface_text: The fact that a stipulation of the kind with which we are companycerned in the present case amounts to a clog on the equity of redemption, is number and cannot be disputed.

arguments.claim: The stipulation as to the mortgagor's liability to re-pay the loan within 15 years did not bar the present suit for redemption because it amounted to a clog on the equity of redemption; transaction was a mortgage not a sale

anchor.surface_text: He urged that the view taken by the trial Court that the stipulation as to the mortgagors liability to re-pay the loan within 15 years did not bar his present suit for redemption, because the said stipulation amounted to a clog on the equity of redemption and as such, could not affect the mortgagors right to redeem, and he added that the transaction, in substance, was a mortgage and not a sale, and so, his right to redeem was alive and be effectively enforced by the present suit.

arguments.claim: The relevant provision as to the period within which the mortgage amount had to be repaid amounted to a clog on the equity of redemption and could not be pleaded as a bar; relevant clause did not clearly make mortgagee absolute owner

anchor.surface_text: The High Court has upheld his first contention that the relevant provision as to the period within which the mortgage amount had to be repaid amounted to a clog on the equity of redemption and could not be pleaded as a bar to the present suit. But on the question about the character of the original transaction itself, the High Court appears to have been inclined to take the view that the relevant clause on which the plea about the bar was raised did not really support the said plea, because it was by no means clear that even after the expiration of 15 years, the mortgagee was intended to be the absolute owner of the property.

Therefore, we feel no difficulty in holding that if the terms of the document were to prevail, the appellants contention that the present suit for redemption is barred, must succeed.

arguments.claim: High Court erred in applying equitable principle because Transfer of Property Act does not apply; relies on Privy Council cases Pattabhiramier and Thumbusawmy enforcing stipulations per ancient law unless legislation or practice

anchor.surface_text: This question arises in this form, because the Transfer of Property Act did not apply to Alwar at the time when the mortgage was executed nor at the time when the 15 years stipulated period expired. Mr. Sarjoo Prasad for the appellant contends that the High Court was in error in applying the equitable principle, because the said principle cannot be invoked in cases where the Transfer of Property Act does not apply. In support of this argument, he has very strongly relied on an early decision of the Privy Council pronounced in 1870, in the case of Pattabhiramier v. Vencatarow Naicken...

arguments.claim: Hindu law applicable to Alwar recognised enforcing promise to repay within time, losing title if not

anchor.surface_text: Basing himself on this position of the Hindu law, Mr. Sarjoo Prasad contends that we ought to assume that Hindu Law which was applicable to Alwar recognised the importance of compelling the mortgagor to perform his promise that he would repay the debt within a specified time and if he failed to do so, he would lose his title over the mortgaged property.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: the principles enunciated by the Privy Council in the cases of Pattabhiramier  1870  13 M.I.A. 560 and Thumbusawmy Moodelly I.L.R. 1 Mad. 1. In dealin

anchor.surface_text: The fact that a stipulation of the kind with which we are concerned in the present case amounts to a clog on the equity of redemption, is not and cannot be disputed.

arguments.claim: Equitable doctrine applies despite no TPA via justice, equity, good conscience mandated by historical regulations and High Court practice

anchor.surface_text: In fact, in Namdeo Lokman Lodhi v. Narmadabai 1953 S.C.R. 1009, this Court has emphatically observed that it is axiomatic that the courts must apply the principles of justice, equity and good conscience to transactions which come before them for determination even though the statutory provisions of the Transfer of Property Act are not made applicable to these transactions.

arguments.claim: Privy Council decisions do not disturb established judicial practice of High Courts enforcing equity against clogs

anchor.surface_text: While pronouncing this decision, Lord Chelmsford, however, took the precaution of adding that while the Board was allowing the appeal, it must not be supposed that their Lordships design to disturb any rule of property established by judicial decisions so as to form part of the Law of the Forum, wherever such may prevail...

arguments.claim: Rajasthan High Court decisions apply s.60 TPA principles via equity even where not in force

anchor.surface_text: In Amba Lal v. Amba Lal I.L.R. 1957 Raj. 964., the Rajasthan High Court held that s. 60 and its proviso contained a general principle of law applicable to mortgages in this country, which should be applicable even in those places where the Transfer of Property Act may not be in force as such, but where its principles may be in force.

arguments.claim: No case made out to interfere with High Court conclusion that stipulation cannot be enforced as clog

anchor.surface_text: We are, therefore, satisfied that no case has been made out by the appellant to justify our interference with the conclusion of the Rajasthan High Court that the relevant stipulation on which the appellant relies ought not to be enforced even though it creates a clog on the equity of redemption.

holdings.text: The relevant clause in the mortgage deed intends to make the mortgagee the absolute owner of the property at the end of 15 years if the debt is not paid within that period.

anchor.surface_text: If that is the meaning of the relevant words, it seems difficult to accept the view that the document did number intend to make the mortgagee the owner of the property at the end of 15 years if the debt due was number paid within that period. When the document says that there would be numberscope for the mortgagor to say anything, it necessarily means, in the companytext, that the mortgagor would, in that case, have lost his title to the property, and that means the mortgagee would become the absolute owner of the property. Therefore, we feel numberdifficulty in holding that if the terms of the document were to prevail, the appellants companytention that the present suit for redemption is barred, must succeed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation of clause, especially 'Mala Kalam' meaning no scope for mortgagor to assert rights, implying loss of title and absolute ownership for mortgagee.

holdings.text: The stipulation extinguishing mortgagor's right after 15 years amounts to a clog on the equity of redemption.

anchor.surface_text: The fact that a stipulation of the kind with which we are companycerned in the present case amounts to a clog on the equity of redemption, is number and cannot be disputed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Common ground; such time-bound forfeiture clauses restrict the paramount equity of redemption inherent in mortgages.

holdings.text: The equitable doctrine against clogs on equity of redemption applies even where Transfer of Property Act does not apply, through principles of justice, equity and good conscience.

anchor.surface_text: does the equitable doctrine ensuring the mortgagors equity of redemption in spite of a clog created on such equity by stipulations in the mortgage deed apply to the present case ? ... We are, therefore, satisfied that no case has been made out by the appellant to justify our interference with the conclusion of the Rajasthan High Court that the relevant stipulation on which the appellant relies ought to be enforced even though it creates a clog on the equity of redemption.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Historical regulations mandate JEGC; consistent High Court practice enforcing equity over strict stipulations; SC precedent in Namdeo; Privy Council cases distinguished due to established judicial practice; Rajasthan HC decisions analogous.

anchor.surface_text: If that is the meaning of the relevant words, it seems difficult to accept the view that the document did number intend to make the mortgagee the owner of the property at the end of 15 years if the debt due was number paid within that period. When the document says that there would be numberscope for the mortgagor to say anything, it necessarily means, in the companytext, that the mortgagor would, in that case, have lost his title to the property, and that means the mortgagee would become the absolute owner of the property. Therefore, we feel numberdifficulty in holding that if the terms of the document were to prevail, the appellants companytention that the present suit for redemption is barred, must succeed.

We are, therefore, satisfied that numbercase has been made out by the appellant to justify our interference with the companyclusion of the Rajasthan High Court that the relevant stipulation on which the appellant relies ought to be enforced even
